Key Findings

  • £596,100 in likely duplicate payments across 26 high-confidence groups
  • A further £11.5 million in medium-confidence possible duplicates (2,069 groups)
  • £2.1 million in suspected split payments — 10 instances of purchases just below procurement thresholds placed in the same week

What We Found

When the same supplier receives the same amount on the same day three or more times, it raises questions. After filtering out 2,612 CSV republication artifacts (where quarterly data overlaps), our analysis identified 26 groups of likely duplicate payments totalling £596,100.

These aren't necessarily errors — some may be legitimate recurring payments. But without invoice-level detail (which Lancaster doesn't publish), it's impossible to confirm whether these represent genuine duplicate payments or planned spending.

The Split Payment Question

We also flagged 10 instances where multiple payments to the same supplier fell just below procurement thresholds within the same week, totalling £2.1 million. This pattern can indicate deliberate splitting of orders to avoid competitive tendering requirements, though it can also reflect genuine operational needs.

View the evidence on our Spending page.
